thread.title: Dalvin Cook remains day-to-day with hamstring injury; updates on Andrews, Smith, Pender
thread.title_full: Dalvin Cook remains day-to-day with hamstring injury; updates on Andrews, Smith, Pender

title: Dalvin Cook remains day-to-day with hamstring injury; updates on Andrews, Smith, Pender
text:
Dalvin Cook is held on the sideline after coming up lame and holding the back of his leg on a play against Wake Forest on Saturday at BB&T Field. (Photo: Joe Rondone/Democrat)
66 CONNECT 19 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Updated post: If Dalvin Cook is not ready to play against Miami on Saturday, Florida State coach Jimbo Fisher has faith in his backup running backs.
Cook, FSU’s leader on offense with 507 yards rushing and six touchdowns, remains day-to-day with hamstring injury he suffered against Wake Forest, Fisher said on Monday.
Fisher said there’s a possibility Cook could miss Saturday’s game against Miami set for an 8 p.m. kickoff on ABC. He’ll be held out of practice on Monday and Tuesday.
Cook was knocked out of the previous game — against Boston College on Sept. 19 — with an upper-body injury, but returned to the game and practiced during FSU's bye week.
“He’s a guy who heals pretty quickly and plays tough, but you can’t count on that,” Fisher said of Cook during his weekly press conference Monday. “He’s got to wait it day by day and see how it goes.”
TALLAHASSEE DEMOCRAT
No. 9 Seminoles leave Wake Forest with 24-16 victory
Cook was taken out of the game after suffering the hamstring injury in the first quarter. Fisher said the injury was not as bad as initially thought.
Sophomore Johnathan Vickers, who scored his first career rushing touchdown against Wake Forest, and five-star freshman Jacques Patrick will backup Cook.
Vickers, who caught a touchdown pass in the season opener from backup quarterback Sean Maguire, finished the game with 10 carries for 33 yards. Patrick, rated a five-star tailback by several recruiting outlets, only had three carries for 13 yards.
“I feel good about Vickers and Patrick,” Fisher said. “Those guys are really good.”
Redshirt junior Mario Pender, who suffered a collapsed lung in practice on Sept. 22 and needed surgery last week, is still in the hospital recovering, but Fisher is “getting good reports back.”
“He’s getting better and better,” Fisher said of Pender. “Thank God.”
The Seminoles also had two other players suffer injuries in the first quarter of the Wake Forest game.
Fisher said junior safety Nate Andrews did not tear his ACL in his left knee, but suffered a “bad bone bruise.” Andrews, who led the team in interceptions during his first two seasons, could miss a couple of weeks.
Redshirt senior Terrance Smith suffered a right ankle injury that saw some swelling after the game. Fisher did not share a timetable for Smith’s return.
“They all should be back,” Fisher said. “It’s just a matter of when. I don’t have any idea, and it all depends on each body.”
VIDEOS: JIMBO FISHER, FSU PLAYERS RECAP WIN AT WAKE FOREST Video: Jimbo Fisher says FSU lacks killer instinct after 24-16 win over Wake Forest | 09:52 Florida State coach Jimbo Fisher speaks after the Seminoles beat Wake Forest 24-16 on Saturday, Oct. 3, 2015.

3 of 4 VIDEOS: JIMBO FISHER, FSU PLAYERS RECAP WIN AT WAKE FOREST Video: FSU DE DeMarcus Walker 'so happy' after Wake Forest win | 01:36 Florida State defensive end DeMarcus Walker speaks after the Seminoles beat Wake Forest 24-16 on Saturday, Oct. 3, 2015. Safid Deen/Democrat
4 of 4 Last Video Next Video Video: Jimbo Fisher says FSU lacks killer instinct after 24-16 win over Wake Forest Video: FSU OL Ryan Hoefeld recaps his first start of season against WF Video: FSU WR Travis Rudolph recaps Wake Forest win Video: FSU DE DeMarcus Walker 'so happy' after Wake Forest win Original post: Florida State starting sophomore running back Dalvin Cook remains day-to-day with hamstring injury he suffered against Wake Forest on Saturday, head coach Jimbo Fisher said in a radio interview with ESPN Tallahassee’s Jeff Cameron Show on Monday morning.
Fisher said there’s a possibility Cook, FSU’s leader on offense with 507 yards rushing and six touchdowns, could miss Saturday’s game against Miami set for an 8 p.m. kickoff on ABC.
Fisher also said junior safety Nate Andrews did not tear his ACL in his left knee, but suffered a “bad bone bruise.” Andrews, who led the team in interceptions during his first two seasons, might not play against Miami.
And redshirt senior Terrance Smith suffered a right ankle, lower leg injury that suffered some swelling. Fisher did not share a timetable for Smith’s return.
All three players suffered their injuries during the first quarter of the Wake Forest game.
Cook was knocked out of the previous game — against Boston College on Sept. 19 — with an upper-body injury, but returned to the game and practiced during FSU's bye week.
Fisher will meet with media for his weekly Monday press conference at 1 p.m.
The Seminoles will practice around 4 p.m. today.
Stay tuned to Tallahassee.com for more updates.
Here's the radio interview.
